title: Periodic Table
ghs-01: GHS01 Unstable explosives, self-reactive substances and mixtures, organic peroxides
ghs-02: GHS02 Flammable, self-reactive, self-heating, pyrophoric, combustible, organic peroxides
ghs-05: GHS05 Corrosive to metals, skin corrosion, serious eye damage
ghs-07: GHS07 Labelling of various categories, alone or in addition
glossary-description: Explanation of used terms and units, definition of hazardous substance labeling, etc.
nfpa-h-0: poses no health hazard, requires no precautions, and would offer no hazard beyond that of ordinary combustible materials
nfpa-h-1: exposure would cause irritation with only minor residual injury
nfpa-h-2: intense or continued but not chronic exposure could cause temporary incapacitation or possible residual injury
nfpa-h-3: short exposure could cause serious temporary or moderate residual injury
nfpa-h-4: very short exposure could cause death or major residual injury
nfpa-f-0: materials that will not burn under typical fire conditions
nfpa-f-2: must be moderately heated or exposed to relatively high ambient temperature before ignition can occur
nfpa-f-3: materials that can be ignited under almost all ambient temperature conditions
nfpa-f-4: will rapidly or completely vaporize at normal atmospheric pressure and temperature, or is readily dispersed in air and will burn readily
nfpa-i-0: normally stable, even under fire exposure conditions, and is not reactive with water
nfpa-i-1: normally stable, but can become unstable at elevated temperatures and pressures
nfpa-i-2: undergoes violent chemical change at elevated temperatures and pressures
nfpa-i-3: capable of detonation or explosive decomposition but requires a strong initiating source
nfpa-i-4: readily capable of detonation or explosive decomposition at normal temperatures and pressures
nfpa-s-W: reacts with water in an unusual or dangerous manner
nfpa-s-OX: oxidizer, allows chemicals to burn without an air supply
